entry.et: Middle English, from Old Norse skrapa; akin to Old English scrapian to scrape, Latin scrobis ditch, Russian skresti to scrape

def.dt: :to remove from a surface by usually repeated strokes of an edged instrument
:to make (a surface) smooth or clean with strokes of an edged instrument or an abrasive
:to damage or injure the surface of by contact with a rough surface
:to draw roughly or noisily over a surface
:to collect by or as if by scraping often used with up or together scrape up the price of a ticket
:to move in sliding contact with a rough surface
:to draw back the foot along the ground in making a bow
:to make one's way with difficulty :barely manage or succeed just scraped through at school working two jobs and barely scraping by
:a mark or injury caused by scraping :abrasion bumps and scrapes
:the nest of a bird consisting of a usually shallow depression in the ground
:a cleared area on the forest floor made by a male deer during breeding season to attract a doe
:a bow made with a drawing back of the foot along the ground
:a distressing encounter a scrape with death
